metadata.sermon_title: On Signal: Breaking the Vicious Cycles
metadata.sermon_start_end: My father-in-law, Patrick D. Miller, was a distinguished Presbyterian minister—pastor at Druid Hills Church, denominational executive, and moderator of the General Assembly. One day he and I were discussing how to translate the Lord’s Prayer . . . “forgive us our trespasses, forgive us our sins, forgive us our debts.” [...] My father-in-law had it right. The best thing is to have our debts forgiven. That is why we pray, Forgive us our debts . . . as we forgive our debtors.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails Dekker’s requirement of focusing on ONE specific pericope. It functions as a thematic speech on 'Jubilee,' jumping between Leviticus, Deuteronomy, Isaiah, and Luke. It treats a biblical idea rather than recreating a specific text into a current word.
quotes: Moses—the secret Calvinist—declared as God’s will: every fifty years...
In a related law, Moses chides Israel...
Jesus came to the synagogue and read the scripture lesson from Isaiah 61...
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Select one specific text (e.g., Leviticus 25:8-13) and find what is unique to that passage that cannot be found in the general concept of Jubilee elsewhere.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is a basic awareness of the original context (the 'Canaanite' traders, the 50-year cycle), but it remains superficial. The preacher uses the text to support a socio-economic theory rather than wrestling with the specific Hebrew/Greek nuances of a single passage.
quotes: Indeed, it is likely that the word 'Canaanite,' the ones feared the most by Israel, means 'traders' who bought and sold...
While those old folk did not know about the intricacies of the modern market... they knew all about commerce.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Deepen the linguistic and historical analysis of the specific pericope to move beyond general historical observations.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is the strongest part of the sermon, moving into concrete areas like family resentment, the specific church's role in Atlanta, and public policy. It avoids 'general truths' by addressing the specific 50th anniversary of the congregation.
quotes: Trinity occupies a peculiar position in Atlanta... Your size, your wealth, your special vision...
In Montreat we have an old pie safe that has been there at least thirty-five years... a cousin observes, 'that really belongs to me.'
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Ensure the application is derived strictly from the exposition of the text rather than from a general sociological vision of 'neighborliness'.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon follows a somewhat modular structure (I, II, III, IV), which Dekker warns against as it can separate exposition and application. However, the preacher attempts to draw the hearer into the 'vicious cycles' throughout.
quotes: I want to tell you three things about Jubilee as you ponder how Trinity should practice it...
And now comes Trinity—fifty years—Jubilee to face this hard practice...
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Avoid the numbered list structure (I, II, III); allow the text's movement to dictate the sermon's flow so that application is 'mixed' with the word.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The sermon focuses heavily on 'misery' (economic greed, resentment) and 'gratitude' (neighborliness), but the 'redemption' is largely horizontal/ethical rather than vertical/Trinitarian. It risks being too human-oriented without a strong sense of the Spirit's work.
quotes: Every family I know lives partly by an intricate practice of debt management, of old wounds remembered...
God’s rule where the practices of justice and mercy and kindness and peaceableness are every day the order of the day.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Strengthen the Trinitarian background; show how the 'misery' of greed is specifically misery before God, not just a social problem.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon touches on the 'vicious cycles' and 'ruined cities,' but it lacks the sharp edge of Dekker's 'two ways.' The possibility of being 'lost' is framed as social failure rather than a theological destination.
quotes: The question of public policy... has to do with our deep gospel conviction that our society is increasingly becoming a jungle of fear and danger...
vicious cycles of violent accumulation are broken.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Address the ultimate seriousness of the human choice; what does it mean for the soul to be 'lost' in the refusal to divest?

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is mentioned as the 'signal' and the enactment of Jubilee, but he appears more as an ethical example or a model for social action than the 'telos' of salvation outside ourselves. The doctrine of the two natures is not felt.
quotes: Jesus is our signal. The jubilee is done...
He set about giving social power and social access and social goods to the poor and excluded.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Move beyond Jesus as a social reformer; show how Christ as God is the only reason grace is the 'deepest of our life'.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 16.5 minutes, the sermon falls short of Dekker’s 20-minute minimum. It lacks the 'breadth' required for true 'depth.'
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exposition and theological reflection to allow the text to breathe beyond 20 minutes.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon functions more as a thematic address on social ethics than a 'recreation of the Bible into a new, current, proclamatory word' as defined by Dekker. It fails the formal requirement of focusing on a single pericope and falls short of the required length for depth. While the application to the specific congregation is concrete, the theological weight is shifted toward horizontal neighborliness at the expense of a vertical, Trinitarian, and Christocentric focus.
strengths: Concrete application to the specific life of the congregation (Trinity's 50th anniversary).
Avoids vague spiritualizations by focusing on material and economic divestment.
Effective use of personal anecdote (the pie safe) to illustrate the 'misery' of resentment.
weaknesses: Thematic approach: uses the Bible as a source for an idea (Jubilee) rather than expounding a specific text.
Insufficient length: under 20 minutes, limiting the potential for theological depth.
Weak Christology: Jesus is presented primarily as a social actor rather than the ontological telos of the sermon.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is not a sermon in the strict sense of Dekker's definition. It is a high-quality ethical speech that uses biblical motifs, but it lacks the formal specificity of pericope-based exposition and the substantive weight of the 'two ways' and 'one Lord' required for true proclamation.
